elements.content: A novel three-dimensional (3D) microporous lanthanide−organic framework [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)(H2O)] n ·2nH2O (1) has been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. The results of an X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D nanotubular structure. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 1 can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (42638) as a zeolite ABW net. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm.
elements.clean_text: A novel three-dimensional (3D) microporous lanthanide-organic framework [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)(H2O)] n ⋅2nH2O (1) has been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. The results of an X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D nanotubular structure. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 1 can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (42638) as a zeolite ABW net. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm.

elements.content: A novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide−organic framework with nanotubular structure has been obtained. The framework can be considered as a lanthanide−organic analogue of zeolite ABW with (42638) topology. The water molecule filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm.
elements.clean_text: A novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide-organic framework with nanotubular structure has been obtained. The framework can be considered as a lanthanide-organic analogue of zeolite ABW with (42638) topology. The water molecule filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm.

elements.content: Zeolites as open-framework aluminosilicates are important industrial materials that are widely used as catalysts, additives for detergents, and adsorbents. In recent years, the design and synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) that are structurally analogous to porous zeolites have attracted considerable attention in materials chemistry due to the formation of fascinating topologies and potential applications for gas storage, small molecule separation, and enantiomer resolution. The advantage of MOFs over analogous zeolites is that their cavity size, shape, and functionality can be systematically and predictably adjusted via synthetic modification of the organic ligand. Various strategies have been made to construct porous MOFs. However, most of the work has so far centered on the assembly of the d-block metal−organic open frameworks, and the analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains less developed, although several research groups have reported some interesting findings. Because the lanthanide ions generally have higher coordination numbers than the d-block metal ions, it is more likely to incorporate ancillary ligands (such as water molecules) into lanthanide coordination networks. Such ancillary ligands may be removed keeping the lanthanide−organic framework intact, thereby generating porous solids with coordinatively unsaturated lanthanide ions that may have potential catalytic activity. Now that these lanthanide−organic frameworks have been shown to be very promising materials, efforts are underway to determine what chemical factors are desirable for constructing porous lanthanide−organic frameworks. Herein, we present a novel zeolitic lanthanide−organic framework with nanotubular structure.
elements.clean_text: Zeolites as open-framework aluminosilicates are important industrial materials that are widely used as catalysts, additives for detergents, and adsorbents. In recent years, the design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that are structurally analogous to porous zeolites have attracted considerable attention in materials chemistry due to the formation of fascinating topologies and potential applications for gas storage, small molecule separation, and enantiomer resolution. The advantage of MOFs over analogous zeolites is that their cavity size, shape, and functionality can be systematically and predictably adjusted via synthetic modification of the organic ligand. Various strategies have been made to construct porous MOFs. However, most of the work has so far centered on the assembly of the d-block metal-organic open frameworks, and the analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains less developed, although several research groups have reported some interesting findings. Because the lanthanide ions generally have higher coordination numbers than the d-block metal ions, it is more likely to incorporate ancillary ligands (such as water molecules) into lanthanide coordination networks. Such ancillary ligands may be removed keeping the lanthanide-organic framework intact, thereby generating porous solids with coordinatively unsaturated lanthanide ions that may have potential catalytic activity. Now that these lanthanide-organic frameworks have been shown to be very promising materials, efforts are underway to determine what chemical factors are desirable for constructing porous lanthanide-organic frameworks. Herein, we present a novel zeolitic lanthanide-organic framework with nanotubular structure.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O, Mn(Ac)2·4H2O, and H22,5-pydc (pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate acid) in a molar ratio of 2:1:2 at 160 °C for 3 days yielded purple crystals of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)(H2O)] n ·2nH2O (1).
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reaction of Nd(NO3)3⋅6H2O, Mn(Ac)2⋅4H2O, and H22,5-pydc (pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate acid) in a molar ratio of 2:1:2 at 160 °C for 3 days yielded purple crystals of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)(H2O)] n ⋅2nH2O (1).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 revealed a three-dimensional (3D) zeolitic coordination polymer that crystallizes in the space group P21 /n. There is one NdIII ion, one 2,5-pydc2− ligand, one Ac1− anion, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice–water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The NdIII ion is nine-coordinated in the shape of a tricapped trigonal prism geometry by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four 2,5-pydc2− ligands, three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two Ac1− anions, one aqua oxygen atom, and a pyridyl nitrogen atom (Figure ). Each 2,5-pydc2− ligand acts as a µ4-bridge to link four NdIII ions, in which the nitrogen atom and one oxygen atom of the 2-carboxylate group chelate a NdIII ion and both the carboxylate groups adopt a µ2-η1:η1-bridging coordination mode. Each Ac1− anion adopts a µ2-η2:η1-bridging coordination mode to ligate to two NdIII ions (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 revealed a three-dimensional (3D) zeolitic coordination polymer that crystallizes in the space group P21 /n. There is one NdIII ion, one 2,5-pydc2- ligand, one Ac1- anion, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice-water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The NdIII ion is nine-coordinated in the shape of a tricapped trigonal prism geometry by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four 2,5-pydc2- ligands, three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two Ac1- anions, one aqua oxygen atom, and a pyridyl nitrogen atom (Figure ). Each 2,5-pydc2- ligand acts as a µ4-bridge to link four NdIII ions, in which the nitrogen atom and one oxygen atom of the 2-carboxylate group chelate a NdIII ion and both the carboxylate groups adopt a µ2-η1:η1-bridging coordination mode. Each Ac1- anion adopts a µ2-η2:η1-bridging coordination mode to ligate to two NdIII ions (Scheme ).

elements.content: The coordination environments of Nd1 atom in 1. Symmetry codes: A: −x, −y, −z; B: 1 − x, y, −z; C: x − 1, y, z.

elements.content: Coordination modes of 2,5-pydc2− lignads and Ac1− anions in the structure of 1
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination modes of 2,5-pydc2- lignads and Ac1- anions in the structure of 1

elements.content: The NdIII ions are interconnected through 2,5-pydc2− ligands and Ac1− anions to generate an intricate 3D architecture. Herein, we describe it stepwise. Two NdIII ions are first linked together through one Ac1− anion to generate a dinuclear unit (Figure a), and then these dinuclear units are further linked via 2-carboxylate groups of 2,5-pydc2− ligands to form a sheet in the [100] plane (Figure c). The sheet can be represented topologically by the dinuclear units and the connections between them as an ordered (4,4) net. Very intriguingly, a careful examination shows that there exist parallel helical chains, which are formed by 2-carboxylate groups bridging NdIII ions along the b-axis with a pitch of 6.447 Å (Figure b). Therefore, the sheet can be considered as being constructed by Ac1−-linked helical chains. The helices with opposite chirality are arranged alternately along the c-axis, so that the whole sheet is achiral. On the other hand, two NdIII ions are also bridged via 5-carboxylate groups of 2,5-pydc2− ligands to generate dinuclear units that are further linked via pyridyl nitrogen to form a linear chain along the a-axis (Figure d). The chain pillared above order (4,4) sheet together by sharing NdIII ions to generate the final 3D framework with nanotubular structure (Figure ). In the resulting framework, there exist one-dimensional channels along the a-axis (dimensions 6.4 × 12.0 Å2). The NdIII ions and 2,5-pydc2− ligands act as walls of the channels, while the Ac1− anions, the coordinated water molecules and lattice–water molecules filled the channels.
elements.clean_text: The NdIII ions are interconnected through 2,5-pydc2- ligands and Ac1- anions to generate an intricate 3D architecture. Herein, we describe it stepwise. Two NdIII ions are first linked together through one Ac1- anion to generate a dinuclear unit (Figure a), and then these dinuclear units are further linked via 2-carboxylate groups of 2,5-pydc2- ligands to form a sheet in the [100] plane (Figure c). The sheet can be represented topologically by the dinuclear units and the connections between them as an ordered (4,4) net. Very intriguingly, a careful examination shows that there exist parallel helical chains, which are formed by 2-carboxylate groups bridging NdIII ions along the b-axis with a pitch of 6.447 Å (Figure b). Therefore, the sheet can be considered as being constructed by Ac1--linked helical chains. The helices with opposite chirality are arranged alternately along the c-axis, so that the whole sheet is achiral. On the other hand, two NdIII ions are also bridged via 5-carboxylate groups of 2,5-pydc2- ligands to generate dinuclear units that are further linked via pyridyl nitrogen to form a linear chain along the a-axis (Figure d). The chain pillared above order (4,4) sheet together by sharing NdIII ions to generate the final 3D framework with nanotubular structure (Figure ). In the resulting framework, there exist one-dimensional channels along the a-axis (dimensions 6.4 × 12.0 Å2). The NdIII ions and 2,5-pydc2- ligands act as walls of the channels, while the Ac1- anions, the coordinated water molecules and lattice-water molecules filled the channels.

elements.content: (a) Dinuclear unit linked through Ac1− anion. (b) Helical chain formed by 2-carboxylate groups of pydc ligands. (c) The ordered (4,4) sheet formed by Ac1−-linked helical chains. (d) The linear chain pillaring the (4,4) sheets.
elements.clean_text: 2   (a) Dinuclear unit linked through Ac1- anion. (b) Helical chain formed by 2-carboxylate groups of pydc ligands. (c) The ordered (4,4) sheet formed by Ac1--linked helical chains. (d) The linear chain pillaring the (4,4) sheets.

elements.content: Perspective view of the three-dimensional prototypical zeolitic framework with nanotubular structure.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective view of the three-dimensional prototypical zeolitic framework with nanotubular structure.

elements.content: A better insight into the nature of this intricate framework can be achieved by the application of a topological approach. As discussed above, each NdIII ion links four 2,5-pydc2− ligand, and each 2,5-pydc2− ligand ligates to four NdIII ions, thus defining both four-connected nodes. From the topological point of view, the structure of 1 is a uninodal four-connected net (Figure b). Interestingly, the network of 1 can be considered as the lanthanide−organic analogue of the zeolite Li-A (Barrer and White) (ABW), with the Schläfli symbol (42638). As the structure of a zeolite ABW, the periodic building unit (PerBU) of the network of 1 is also a layer of six-membered rings (Figure a). Neighboring PerBUs are connected through four-membered rings to generate the final net. Like the zeolite ABW, the network of 1 contains eight-membered channels that are formed from four NdIII ions and four 2,5-pydc2− ligands. Replacement of the four-connected nodes of zeolite ABW, Si, and Al, with the NdIII ions and 2,5-pydc2− ligands, replicates and expands the 3.4 × 3.8 Å eight-membered channels to approximately 6.4 × 12.0 Å2.
elements.clean_text: A better insight into the nature of this intricate framework can be achieved by the application of a topological approach. As discussed above, each NdIII ion links four 2,5-pydc2- ligand, and each 2,5-pydc2- ligand ligates to four NdIII ions, thus defining both four-connected nodes. From the topological point of view, the structure of 1 is a uninodal four-connected net (Figure b). Interestingly, the network of 1 can be considered as the lanthanide-organic analogue of the zeolite Li-A (Barrer and White) (ABW), with the Schläfli symbol (42638). As the structure of a zeolite ABW, the periodic building unit (PerBU) of the network of 1 is also a layer of six-membered rings (Figure a). Neighboring PerBUs are connected through four-membered rings to generate the final net. Like the zeolite ABW, the network of 1 contains eight-membered channels that are formed from four NdIII ions and four 2,5-pydc2- ligands. Replacement of the four-connected nodes of zeolite ABW, Si, and Al, with the NdIII ions and 2,5-pydc2- ligands, replicates and expands the 3.4 × 3.8 Å eight-membered channels to approximately 6.4 × 12.0 Å2.

elements.content: (a) PerBU in network of 1. (b) Topological view of the three-dimensional network of 1 with zeolite ABW topology. Nd nodes are represented by blue balls and pydc2− nodes are represented by pink balls.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) PerBU in network of 1. (b) Topological view of the three-dimensional network of 1 with zeolite ABW topology. Nd nodes are represented by blue balls and pydc2- nodes are represented by pink balls.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compounds 1 in the temperature range 30–800 °C (). The first weight loss in the temperature range of 140–200 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice–water molecules, and the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred in the temperature range of 200–260 °C. No further weight loss was observed until it reached 400 °C, at which the decomposition of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)] n occurred. After hypothetical removal of the water molecules of 1, 1 is exceptionally microporous, with a solvent-accessible volume of 20.7% calculated using PLATON. The dehydrated 1 retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound, as supported by the consistent X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns ().
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compounds 1 in the temperature range 30-800 °C (). The first weight loss in the temperature range of 140-200 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice-water molecules, and the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred in the temperature range of 200-260 °C. No further weight loss was observed until it reached 400 °C, at which the decomposition of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)] n  occurred. After hypothetical removal of the water molecules of 1, 1 is exceptionally microporous, with a solvent-accessible volume of 20.7% calculated using PLATON. The dehydrated 1 retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound, as supported by the consistent X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns ().

elements.content: Compound 1 exhibits permanent porosity, which has been confirmed by gas sorption. Prior to gas sorption experiments, guest water molecules and possibly axial aqua ligands are removed by thermal activation at the optimized temperature of 260 °C. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm, which is relatively high compared to those of microporous zeolites and aluminophosphates ().
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 exhibits permanent porosity, which has been confirmed by gas sorption. Prior to gas sorption experiments, guest water molecules and possibly axial aqua ligands are removed by thermal activation at the optimized temperature of 260 °C. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm, which is relatively high compared to those of microporous zeolites and aluminophosphates ().

elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 1 were performed on the polycrystalline sample in the temperature range 2–300 K under a 5 KOe external field. The µeff value for per NdIII ion is equal to 3.73 µB at room temperature, slightly higher than the expected value of 3.62 µB for free NdIII with a 4I9/2 ground state, and decreases continuously to a value of 1.99 µB at 2 K. The continuous decrease of the value µeff for 1 may be due to the depopulation of the stark levels for a single NdIII ion and/or possible antiferromagntic interactions between NdIII ions within the Ac1− bridged dinuclear units.
elements.clean_text: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 1 were performed on the polycrystalline sample in the temperature range 2-300 K under a 5 KOe external field. The µeff value for per NdIII ion is equal to 3.73 µB at room temperature, slightly higher than the expected value of 3.62 µB for free NdIII with a 4I9/2 ground state, and decreases continuously to a value of 1.99 µB at 2 K. The continuous decrease of the value µeff for 1 may be due to the depopulation of the stark levels for a single NdIII ion and/or possible antiferromagntic interactions between NdIII ions within the Ac1- bridged dinuclear units.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have demonstrated a novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide−organic framework with nanotubular structure. The solvent of crystallization and the axial aqua ligands filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have demonstrated a novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide-organic framework with nanotubular structure. The solvent of crystallization and the axial aqua ligands filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure.

cln_elements.content:
A novel three-dimensional (3D) microporous lanthanide−organic framework [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)(H2O)] n ·2nH2O (1) has been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. The results of an X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D nanotubular structure. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 1 can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (42638) as a zeolite ABW net. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm.

A novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide−organic framework with nanotubular structure has been obtained. The framework can be considered as a lanthanide−organic analogue of zeolite ABW with (42638) topology. The water molecule filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compounds 1 in the temperature range 30–800 °C (). The first weight loss in the temperature range of 140–200 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice–water molecules, and the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred in the temperature range of 200–260 °C. No further weight loss was observed until it reached 400 °C, at which the decomposition of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)] n occurred. After hypothetical removal of the water molecules of 1, 1 is exceptionally microporous, with a solvent-accessible volume of 20.7% calculated using PLATON. The dehydrated 1 retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound, as supported by the consistent X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns ().

Compound 1 exhibits permanent porosity, which has been confirmed by gas sorption. Prior to gas sorption experiments, guest water molecules and possibly axial aqua ligands are removed by thermal activation at the optimized temperature of 260 °C. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g−1 at 1.0 atm, which is relatively high compared to those of microporous zeolites and aluminophosphates ().

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 1 were performed on the polycrystalline sample in the temperature range 2–300 K under a 5 KOe external field. The µeff value for per NdIII ion is equal to 3.73 µB at room temperature, slightly higher than the expected value of 3.62 µB for free NdIII with a 4I9/2 ground state, and decreases continuously to a value of 1.99 µB at 2 K. The continuous decrease of the value µeff for 1 may be due to the depopulation of the stark levels for a single NdIII ion and/or possible antiferromagntic interactions between NdIII ions within the Ac1− bridged dinuclear units.

The results of an X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 1 has a 3D nanotubular structure. From the topological point of view, the intricate 3D framework of compound 1 can be specified by the Schläfli symbol (42638) as a zeolite ABW net. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm.

A novel prototypical zeolitic lanthanide-organic framework with nanotubular structure has been obtained. The framework can be considered as a lanthanide-organic analogue of zeolite ABW with (42638) topology. The water molecule filled in the channels may be completely removed from the porous material without collapse of the host structure. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compounds 1 in the temperature range 30-800 °C (). The first weight loss in the temperature range of 140-200 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice-water molecules, and the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred in the temperature range of 200-260 °C. No further weight loss was observed until it reached 400 °C, at which the decomposition of [Nd(2,5-pydc)(Ac)] n  occurred. After hypothetical removal of the water molecules of 1, 1 is exceptionally microporous, with a solvent-accessible volume of 20.7% calculated using PLATON. The dehydrated 1 retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound, as supported by the consistent X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns ().

Compound 1 exhibits permanent porosity, which has been confirmed by gas sorption. Prior to gas sorption experiments, guest water molecules and possibly axial aqua ligands are removed by thermal activation at the optimized temperature of 260 °C. The H2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K shows an uptake of 132 cm3 g-1 at 1.0 atm, which is relatively high compared to those of microporous zeolites and aluminophosphates (). 

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 1 were performed on the polycrystalline sample in the temperature range 2-300 K under a 5 KOe external field. The µeff value for per NdIII ion is equal to 3.73 µB at room temperature, slightly higher than the expected value of 3.62 µB for free NdIII with a 4I9/2 ground state, and decreases continuously to a value of 1.99 µB at 2 K. The continuous decrease of the value µeff for 1 may be due to the depopulation of the stark levels for a single NdIII ion and/or possible antiferromagntic interactions between NdIII ions within the Ac1- bridged dinuclear units.

metadata.title: A Prototypical Zeolitic Lanthanide−Organic Framework with Nanotubular Structure
